The current theory that the Earth orbits the Sun has two major flaws and a minor one (one of these major flaws also dismisses geocentrism and so is included under that heading instead):
1. The Earth is stationary

In the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, a couple of experiments were carried out with light which inadvertently determined that the Earth didn’t move and that the “luminous aether” existed. You can imagine that caused quite a furor.
The Michelson-Morely experiment
Michelson and Morely

shone a light the same distance but in two directions. One in the same direction the Earth travels around the Sun and one at right angles; both via mirrors. This light was captured in the same eyepiece to see how much the light infringed. The more the infringement, the more the light had slowed down.

children.note: Malcom Bowden. “Michelson-Morely experiment.” Odysee.

children.text: They assumed the light travelling in the same direction as the Earth travels would hit the detector last because the aether was moving in the opposite direction and light travelled through the aether, like a fish swimming upstream. The difference should be the speed of the orbit of the Earth around the Sun which is around 30 km/s. Instead they detected a slower varied speed of between 1 and 10 km/s which they called a “null” result (Fig. 1.1).
They thought there might be possible daily and seasonal changes, so they repeated the experiment in 12 hours and also in 6 months with the same result. They thought that maybe the mass of the
Earth dragged the aether

along with it. So they took the apparatus up on top of a mountain, hoping that the mountain would be sticking up into the aether that was not being dragged by the Earth. Again, they got the same result.

The Sagnac experiment
Heliocentrists also completely ignored the obvious conclusions to the followup
Sagnac experiment
in 1913, which also proved the existence of the aether and threw relativity into the garbage heap.

Two light sources were shone at right angles around a spinning round table. One light was shone in the same direction as the table span, the other at right angles, which was the opposite direction. Both lights came back to the one photographic plate via mirrors.

Sagnac found that the light which was shone in the direction of the spinning table arrived later. This was shown by how much the light infringed. Even the speed of the table matched the amount of infringement as it was sped up and down and the directions reversed (Fig. 1.2).

children.text: This conclusively proved that light travels through a substance which they then called the aether. This meant that the Michelson-Morely experiment
proved that the Earth didn’t move

In case you were wondering if this experiment was a one-off, the Sagnac effect is used today as the basis for
Ring Laser Gyroscopes

children.note: Touchberry, Adam. “The Still Amazing Honeywell Ring Laser Gyroscope." Honeywell Aerospace.

children.text: A Ring Laser Gyro (RLG) is a gyroscope that
uses the optical Sagnac effect

to sense rotation. Most commonly, the RLG is filled with a gas, such as Helium Neon (HeNe), and electrodes are used to excite light waves travelling in the clockwise (CW) and counterclockwise (CCW) directions. The light waves travel around an enclosed path steered by a series of mirrors, forming an optical cavity. In the presence of rotation, the clockwise and counterclockwise directions will have different path lengths due to the Optical Sagnac effect. Since the light waves are confined to an optical cavity, the difference in path lengths results in a frequency splitting between the CW and CCW light waves. The difference of frequencies is measured to determine the rotation rate.
As the Earth is not moving, it must be the aether rotating the celestial objects above us every 24 hours. This was demonstrated by yet more science.
The Michelson-Gale experiment
In 1925, long after the failure of the Michelson-Morely experiment to detect Earth’s motion around the Sun in the aether, they wanted to see if they could detect the
24-hour rotation of the Earth
in the aether instead.

They tested this by basically making a huge Michelson-Morely apparatus in order to detect the different aether flows along the surface of the Earth. The aether closer to the equator moves faster than further away, as supposedly the Earth rotates at 1670 kph at the equator and not at all at the poles.

They set up a very large rectangle 613 m wide by 339 m long of 12 inch diameter tubes in a field. One long side was placed on the west-east axis of the Earth towards the north; and the other placed on the same axis but obviously further south closer to the Earth’s equator (Fig. 1.3).

Inside the tubes at each corner were mirrors which reflected light from a light source travelling in opposite directions around the rectangle. The light went back to a screen to see if there would be any infringement. There was also a much shorter inner circuit that was far too short along the east-west axis to detect any change in Earth’s rotation. This smaller circuit was used as a comparison to calibrate.

children.note: Malcom Bowden. “Michelson-Gale experiment." Odysee.

children.text: There were two contradicting predictions as to the result:

According to the new Special Relativity aetherless interpretation of the results of the Michelson-Morely experiment, the light in both circuits should move at the same speed and not show any infringement. This is because they said light moves at a constant speed regardless of the
motion
of the emitting body, so the Earth rotating at different speeds from the poles to the equator wouldn’t matter.

According to the traditional theory of the aether, the light travelling through the north side first will be faster. This is because there is less aether resistance (slower aether current) in the north side tube and greater aether push (faster aether current) in the south side one than for the light travelling in the opposite direction. The latter will experience a greater aether resistance on the south side and less of a push at the north.

They made 269 observations and obtained an average change of 0.230 fringe. This was only a 2.6 percent difference to the calculated change expected of 0.236, which was in line with the angular velocity of the Earth as measured by astronomy. It thus proved the aether drag hypothesis correct and Special Relativity as wishful thinking.

What it didn’t show was whether it was the aether rotating in the heavens or the Earth rotating through a stationary aether. However, since no aether drag was detected in the direction of the Earth orbiting the Sun in the Michelson-Morely experiment we can conclude that the Earth doesn’t move and it is the aether rotating in the heavens.

Conclusion

In a Dyson Sphere, the Sun is just over half a degree from the centre of the cavity and moves horizontally east to west in 24 hours to give us day and night. It also tilts up and down by a total of 46.88° and moves vertically up and down by just under half a degree in total around the horizontal axis during one year to give us the seasons.
